input: As a reserve flight attendant, how many days off am I entitled to in a 30-day bid period?
output: As a reserve flight attendant, you are entitled to at least 12 days off in base in any 30-day bid period. If the bid period is 31 days long, you will be scheduled for at least 13 days off in base.

input: As a flight attendant, how many days off am I entitled to in any 30-day bid period?
output: As a regular flight attendant, you are entitled to at least 13 days off in base in any bid period.

input: As a flight attendant, how are my days off determined if my duty period ends after midnight but before 2 AM?
output: If your duty period is scheduled to terminate before 2400 and actually terminates before 0200, it will be considered to have terminated in the prior calendar day. This means that you will not receive a day off for that day. However, if your duty period is scheduled to terminate before 2400 but actually terminates after 0200, the lost day off shall be restored pursuant to the Day Off Restoration (DOR) provision in Section 8.Y.

input: What is the certification number R-6767, and how does it relate to our crew scheduling?
output: Certification number R-6767 is a recognition made by the National Mediation Board, indicating that the Association of Flight Attendants ("AFA") is the duly designated and authorized representative of the Flight Attendants in the employ of Spirit Airlines, Inc. This certification affects crew scheduling by establishing the AFA as the negotiating body for any changes or agreements related to flight attendant duties, working conditions, and compensation under the Railway Labor Act as amended.

input: As a flight attendant, what are my responsibilities related to Crew Scheduling?
output: As a flight attendant, your primary responsibility related to Crew Scheduling is to follow the schedules provided by the Company and adhere to the regulations governing flight attendants' work hours and rest periods. You should report any discrepancies or concerns regarding your schedule to the appropriate authorities for resolution.

input: Can I be assigned to fly on an aircraft that is not owned by my airline?
output: Yes, you may be assigned to fly on an aircraft that is not owned by your airline if it is under the Company's operational control or leased to the Company. This includes wet leases (aircraft and crew) as well as contracting for other carriers or entities, such as government, military, or commercial operations.

input: Under what circumstances can I be assigned to fly on a contracted aircraft for more than 90 days?
output: You may be assigned to fly on a contracted aircraft for more than 90 days if it is necessary to accomplish the needs of the Company's service and no company flight attendant is furloughed as a result of such contracting out of revenue flying. Additionally, there should not be sufficient aircraft or flight attendants available within the Company to perform the assigned or contracted-out revenue flying.

input: Are code-share agreements allowed under Crew Scheduling regulations?
output: Yes, code-share agreements are allowed under Crew Scheduling regulations as long as they do not result in the furlough of any of the Company's flight attendants. The Company can enter into a code-share agreement, marketing agreement, interline agreement, or pro rate or block space agreement without violating the Crew Scheduling regulations.

input: Can I be assigned to fly on an aircraft that is being dry leased to another airline?
output: No, you cannot be assigned to fly on an aircraft that is being dry leased to another airline. Dry leasing refers to the lease of an aircraft but not its crew, and flight attendants are typically provided by the operating carrier in such cases. As a Spirit Airlines flight attendant, you would not be involved in the operations of a dry-leased aircraft.

input: As a flight attendant, how does the merger of two airlines affect my seniority rights?
output: In the event of a merger between two airlines, the parties involved will make their best efforts to integrate the seniority lists in a fair and equitable manner. This may involve collective bargaining between the carriers and the representatives of the Flight Attendant groups affected. If an agreement cannot be reached, the dispute shall be resolved in accordance with Sections 2, 3, and 13 of the Allegheny-Mohawk Labor Protection Provisions. The integration of the seniority lists will be governed by the AFA Merger Policy if both pre-transaction Flight Attendant groups are represented by the AFA.

input: What happens to my seniority rights during an acquisition of our airline by another company?
output: During an acquisition of your airline by another company, the parties will make their best efforts to integrate the seniority lists in a fair and equitable manner. This may involve collective bargaining between the carriers and the representatives of the Flight Attendant groups affected. If an agreement cannot be reached, the dispute shall be resolved in accordance with Sections 2, 3, and 13 of the Allegheny-Mohawk Labor Protection Provisions. The integration of the seniority lists will be governed by the AFA Merger Policy if both pre-transaction Flight Attendant groups are represented by the AFA.

input: As a flight attendant, how should I expect my seniority rights to be handled during an acquisition by our airline of another carrier?
output: During an acquisition by your airline of another carrier, the parties will make their best efforts to integrate the seniority lists in a fair and equitable manner. This may involve collective bargaining between the carriers and the representatives of the Flight Attendant groups affected. If an agreement cannot be reached, the dispute shall be resolved in accordance with Sections 2, 3, and 13 of the Allegheny-Mohawk Labor Protection Provisions. The integration of the seniority lists will be governed by the AFA Merger Policy if both pre-transaction Flight Attendant groups are represented by the AFA.

input: As a flight attendant, what happens to my seniority rights in case our company merges with another airline and both pre-transaction Flight Attendant groups are not represented by the AFA?
output: If your company merges with another airline and both pre-transaction Flight Attendant groups are not represented by the AFA, the parties will make their best efforts to integrate the seniority lists in a fair and equitable manner. This may involve collective bargaining between the carriers and the representatives of the Flight Attendant groups affected. If an agreement cannot be reached, the dispute shall be resolved in accordance with Sections 2, 3, and 13 of the Allegheny-Mohawk Labor Protection Provisions. In this case, the integration of the seniority lists will not be governed by the AFA Merger Policy.

input: As a flight attendant, how does the fence agreement impact my seniority rights during a consolidation of our airline with another carrier?
output: The fence agreement is an important aspect of the seniority integration process during a consolidation of your airline with another carrier. It helps to establish guidelines and protections for Flight Attendants' seniority rights during the transition period. The specific impact of the fence agreement on your seniority rights will depend on the terms negotiated by the parties involved, but it is intended to ensure that the integration process is fair and equitable for all affected Flight Attendants.

input: Can the Company change our work schedules without consulting us?
output: The Company has the right to determine work schedules, and it is within its discretion to make changes without consulting the flight attendants. However, any changes made will be in compliance with applicable laws and regulations governing flight attendant duties and rest periods.

input: Are flight attendants allowed to have a say in determining their work schedules?
output: While the Company has the ultimate authority to determine work schedules, they may consider input from flight attendants when making decisions. It is important for you to communicate any preferences or concerns you may have regarding your schedule.

input: Can the Company require flight attendants to work unscheduled or irregular hours?
output: Yes, the Company has the right to establish work schedules that include unscheduled or irregular hours, as long as they comply with applicable laws and regulations governing flight attendant duties and rest periods.

input: Are there any restrictions on how the Company can manage its workforce?
output: The Company retains all rights to manage and operate its business and workforce, including the right to increase or decrease the workforce, establish procedures, determine qualifications for employment and promotions, set rules of conduct, evaluate performance, and determine the size and composition of the workforce. However, any actions taken must comply with applicable laws and regulations governing flight attendant duties and rights.

input: Can the Company sell or discontinue parts of its business without our input?
output: Yes, the Company has the right to sell or discontinue all or part of its business without consulting the flight attendants. The decision will be based on the best interests of the company and its operations.

input: Are there any limitations on the type of aircraft we can work on?
output: The Company retains the right to determine the type of aircraft it will use for its operations, and this decision may change without consulting the flight attendants. However, any changes made must comply with applicable laws and regulations governing flight attendant duties and safety requirements.

input: Can you explain the process for resolving disputes related to Section 1 of this contract?
output: Disputes concerning alleged violations of Section 1 will be resolved through final and binding arbitration, expedited before the System Board of Adjustment with a neutral member. The dispute should be heard within 30 days of submission and decided within 60 days, unless both parties agree otherwise in writing. Both sides must abide by any arbitration award issued.

input: What is considered a severe IROP situation?
output: A severe IROP situation is defined as a network flight cancellation rate exceeding or projected to exceed 8% and/or A:14 (on-time arrivals) drops, or an expected drop below 50%, all in one calendar day.

input: What is considered an Aircraft Accident?
output: An Aircraft Accident is defined as an occurrence associated with the operation of an aircraft while it is in motion, during which any person suffers death or serious injury, or when the aircraft receives substantial damage.

input: What is a Base?
output: A Base is a geographic location designated by the Company from which Flight Attendants are regularly awarded or assigned pairings that begin and end at that location. For training assignments, facilities within 25 AAA miles of the base are considered part of the base. Also known as a Domicile.

input: What is a Bid Period?
output: A Bid Period refers to a calendar month with specific exceptions. January spans from January 1 through January 30, February covers the period from January 31 through March 1, and March includes the timeframe from March 2 through March 31.

input: What does Block-to-Block mean?
output: Block-to-Block refers to the period of time that starts when an aircraft first moves for flight purposes or is moved from the ramp blocks and ends when the aircraft is secured with blocks at a ramp or unloading point.

input: What is a Block of Reserve Days?
output: A Block of Reserve Days refers to the reserve day(s) that follow a day off and end with the start of the Flight Attendant's subsequent day off, whether it is Moveable or Immovable.

input: What is a Calendar Day?
output: A Calendar Day refers to a 24-hour period that starts at 0001 Local Time (LT) and ends at 2400 LT.

input: What is a Charter?
output: A Charter is an unscheduled flight operation that is arranged through a contract with a third party, either for commercial purposes or military/government use.

input: What is Check-In Time?
output: Check-In Time refers to the designated moment when a Flight Attendant must report for their assigned duties, as determined by the crew scheduler or other authorized personnel.

input: What is a Closed Base?
output: A Closed Base refers to a location where no vacancies are available for bidding during the monthly vacancy bidding process, meaning that Flight Attendants based there cannot transfer out for the duration of the closed period.

input: What do you mean by the Company?
output: The Company refers to Spirit Airlines, Inc., which is an airline company that operates flights and manages flight attendants and crew schedules according to specific regulations and guidelines.

input: What is Company Date of Hire?
output: The Company Date of Hire refers to the initial date on which an individual began working for Spirit Airlines, Inc., regardless of their current position or role within the company.

input: What is a Day Off?
output: A Day Off refers to a calendar day during which a Flight Attendant is not required to work or perform any duties for the Company, providing them with a break from their responsibilities as a flight attendant.

input: What is Deadheading?
output: Deadheading refers to the transportation by air or surface vehicle of a Flight Attendant from one location to another, arranged by the Company, in order for the Flight Attendant to perform their duties or training as required under this Agreement. This may involve travel between work locations or for training purposes.

input: What is a Domestic Partner?
output: A domestic partner refers to an individual who meets specific criteria, including being at least 18 years old and competent to contract, not being married or in another domestic partnership within the last 90 days, having consent without force, duress, or fraud, agreeing to share basic needs such as food and shelter, and residing with the Flight Attendant for a minimum of six months.

input: What is a Duty Period?
output: A duty period is a specific time frame that begins at the designated location for check-in and continues until the completion of debriefing after landing, or when released, whichever occurs last.

input: What is a Ferry Flight?
output: A ferry flight refers to an aircraft journey between two airports without any paying passengers on board. This type of flight may be used for transporting the aircraft itself or for moving crew members and their luggage to their designated work location.

input: What is a Final Schedule?
output: A final schedule refers to a Flight Attendant's monthly work plan, which has been adjusted and finalized following any necessary changes or modifications. This schedule outlines the flight assignments, duty periods, and other relevant details for the attendant during that specific month.

input: Who is a Flight Attendant?
output: A flight attendant is an employee who meets the requirements set by both Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) and company regulations, holds a position on the company's seniority list, and is responsible for ensuring passenger safety, comfort, and service during flights, as well as carrying out other duties assigned by the company.

input: What is a Flight Segment?
output: A flight segment refers to a single journey between two specific airports, also known as a "flight leg." For example, the route from Detroit Metropolitan Wayne County Airport (DTW) to Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport (FLL) would consist of one flight segment.

input: Who is considered part of the General Population?
output: The general population includes all non-represented employees, ranging from entry-level workers to senior managers within a company or organization.

input: What is Home Study?
output: Home study refers to company-mandated training that a flight attendant can complete at their preferred location and time, provided it is before the specified deadline. This allows for flexibility in learning while still adhering to the required standards set by the company.

input: What is an Incident?
output: An incident refers to any event that takes place during aircraft operations, excluding an aircraft accident, which may impact or have the potential to influence the safety of those involved in the operation. These incidents can range from minor issues to more significant concerns and must be reported and addressed accordingly.

input: What does International mean?
output: When used in the context of flight operations, "international" refers to any flying or deadheading (travel by crew members when they are not working on a scheduled flight) that takes place outside the contiguous 48 states of the United States. This definition excludes Alaska, Canada, Mexico, and the island nations in the Caribbean between 15 degrees north latitude and 28 degrees north latitude, with the exception of Cuba.

input: What are Irregular Operations?
output: Irregular operations refer to any deviation from normal flight procedures that result from factors outside the control of the airline company. These can include mechanical issues, adverse weather conditions, air traffic control-related delays, or late aircraft arrivals. Such irregularities require adjustments to be made in order to maintain safety and minimize disruptions for passengers and crew members.

input: What is Known Flying?
output: "Known flying" refers to flight operations that are planned with a reasonable degree of certainty based on historical data and records. This typically includes scheduled service flights, firm military charter flights, scheduled charter flights, and other charter flights that have demonstrated consistent operating patterns in the past.

input: What is a Layover?
output: A layover refers to the period of time during which a flight attendant is relieved from their duties and allowed to rest while being away from their base of operations. This typically occurs when crew members are on a trip that involves an overnight stay or extended period of time between flights, providing them with an opportunity to recuperate before resuming their responsibilities.

input: What is a Lead-in Trip?
output: A lead-in trip refers to a flight schedule pairing that is planned to depart during one bidding period (a process where crew members can select their preferred schedules) and is intended to be completed within the following bidding period.

input: What is a Lead Position?
output: A lead position refers to the ‘A’ seat on an aircraft, which is designated at the check-in time for a particular trip. It is assigned in seniority order, with more experienced crew members being offered this role first. The lead position is typically given to those who have completed their probationary period and are considered regular flight attendants. In reverse seniority order, exclusive of probationary flight attendants, the lead position is assigned to ensure fairness and adherence to company policies.

input: What is a Line?
output: A line refers to a predetermined sequence of duty assignments within a specific bidding period at a particular base. This may include individual flight pairings, training sessions, and days off. Flight attendants can bid on or request specific lines during the bidding process, hoping to secure their preferred schedule for the upcoming period. The goal is to create an efficient and manageable workload while ensuring adequate rest and time off for each crew member.

input: What is Longevity?
output: Longevity refers to the duration of time that begins on the date an individual completes their initial flight attendant training and continues to accumulate while they are actively working as a flight attendant. This period takes into account breaks in service, such as vacation or sick leave, but only if the flight attendant remains in the classification. Longevity is an important factor in determining scheduling preferences, as it reflects the experience and seniority of the flight attendant within the company.

input: What is Open Time?
output: Open time refers to any unassigned flight pairings that are accessible for selection or exchange among crew members, provided the transaction adheres to the guidelines outlined in Sections 8K and 8L. These sections detail the rules and regulations governing the pickup or trade of open time slots, ensuring fairness and equity within the scheduling process. Open time allows flight attendants to adjust their schedules as needed, providing flexibility and accommodating personal preferences or unforeseen circumstances.

input: What are Pairing(s)?
output: A pairing refers to the itinerary of flight segments, deadheading (non-revenue flights), ferry flights, and training that begins at the flight attendant's base and concludes with their return to that same location. This pairing includes all scheduled activities from Check-in Time until the end of the duty period. Pairings are essential components of a flight attendant's schedule, as they outline the specific flights and related tasks they will be responsible for during their assigned shift.

input: What are Patterns?
output: Patterns refer to the organized arrangement of pairings on specific lines or routes. These patterns can include various configurations such as having the same trip, maintaining consistent days off, ensuring all weekends off, or working only morning or afternoon departures. The purpose of patterns is to provide structure and consistency in crew scheduling, allowing flight attendants to better plan their personal lives and accommodate recurring preferences or needs.

input: What is Positive Contact?
output: Positive Contact refers to direct and personal communication between a flight attendant and their crew scheduler, either in person, via phone call, or through electronic means such as ACARS (Aeronautical Communication Addressing and Reporting System) or an electronic notification app. The purpose of positive contact is to notify the flight attendant of their assignment, provide essential information related to their duties, and facilitate clear communication regarding any changes or updates in their schedule. Positive Contact ensures that flight attendants are well-informed and able to plan accordingly.

input: What are Qualifications?
output: Qualifications refer to the certifications or training requirements that enable a flight attendant to bid for and hold specific positions on a particular line or pairing. Under the agreement, the only qualification recognized is language proficiency. This means that flight attendants who possess the necessary language skills can bid for and be assigned to flights requiring those languages, allowing them to utilize their expertise and contribute effectively to the overall operation.

input: What is a Relief Line?
output: A Relief Line refers to a monthly schedule that is created and awarded after the initial bids have been assigned and posted as the Final Schedule. The Relief Line initially has no scheduled activities or days off, but it is included in the bid packet for flight attendants to bid on. This line serves as an additional option for those who may not have received their preferred schedule during the initial bidding process, providing them with a chance to secure a more suitable arrangement later in the month.

input: What is a Reserve Line?
output: A Reserve Line is a monthly schedule that is posted by the company for flight attendants to bid on. This line includes intervening notification periods and planned days off, which means that there are breaks between scheduled shifts and designated time for rest. The purpose of the Reserve Line is to provide additional opportunities for flight attendants who may not have received their preferred schedule during the initial bidding process or who wish to adjust their existing arrangements. By bidding on the Reserve Line, flight attendants can potentially secure a more favorable schedule that better suits their needs and preferences.

input: What is a Reroute?
output: A Reroute refers to a situation in which a Lineholder, following the established order of assignment and in inverse seniority order among available and eligible flight attendants, is involuntarily reassigned to an uncovered segment or trip. This can occur when there are insufficient crew members to cover all scheduled flights, or when changes are made to the original trip itinerary. In such cases, a Reroute takes place to ensure that all flights remain staffed with qualified and available flight attendants, even if it means reassigning personnel from their originally planned schedules.

input: What is a Reschedule?
output: A Reschedule occurs when a Lineholder's pairing or schedule is altered by Crew Scheduling in response to a schedule disruption. This may happen due to factors such as flight delays, misconnections, cancellations, rest conflicts, or other unforeseen events that impact the original plan. In these cases, Crew Scheduling will reassign the Lineholder to a new pairing or modify their schedule to ensure continuity of operations and maintain compliance with regulations governing flight attendant duties and rest periods.

input: What is a Rest Period?
output: A Rest Period refers to a specified period of time that is contractually or regulatorily mandated for the purpose of providing flight attendants with rest. During this time, flight attendants are released from all duties and responsibilities associated with their job, allowing them to recuperate and rejuvenate before returning to work. Rest periods are essential for maintaining compliance with regulations governing flight attendant duties and ensuring that they remain well-rested and capable of performing their responsibilities effectively.

input: What is a Retiree?
output: A Retiree is a flight attendant who has chosen to leave the company's employment voluntarily and meets specific criteria related to years of service and age. To qualify as a retiree, a flight attendant must have at least ten (10) years of active service with the company and have reached their 55th birthday. Alternatively, a flight attendant with at least 15 years of active service who voluntarily leaves the employment of the company will also be considered a retiree for the purpose of retiree travel passes. Retirees are eligible for certain benefits and privileges, including access to special travel arrangements.

input: What does Schedule Integrity mean for a Flight Attendant?
output: Schedule integrity is an entitlement that ensures a flight attendant can fly their assigned trip(s) without being rerouted, provided that the flight attendant's trip operates and they are legally allowed to fly it. Additionally, the flight attendant's days off on the final bid award must remain intact as their minimum days off for that specific bidding month. This means that a flight attendant's schedule should be respected and maintained, allowing them to enjoy the trips they have been awarded without unexpected changes or disruptions. Schedule integrity helps maintain fairness and consistency in crew scheduling while providing flight attendants with the stability they need for personal planning.

input: What is considered as Scheduled Time?
output: Scheduled time refers to the specific times that have been predetermined and documented in the operating schedules created by the company. These scheduled times include the departure and arrival times of flights, as well as any other relevant timeframes associated with a particular flight or crew member's duties. The scheduled time serves as a reference point for both the airline and its employees, ensuring that everyone is aware of their responsibilities and obligations during each stage of the operation. This helps maintain efficiency, organization, and adherence to regulations within the aviation industry.

input: What constitutes as a Serious Injury?
output: A serious injury is defined as an injury that impedes or prevents a flight attendant from carrying out their regular flight duties. This could include physical limitations, disabilities, or medical conditions that render the individual unable to perform essential functions required by their job. In such cases, the affected flight attendant may be entitled to certain benefits and accommodations, as well as time off work to recover and rehabilitate. It is important for flight attendants to report any serious injuries to their employer promptly, as this will enable the company to provide appropriate support and ensure compliance with relevant regulations governing employee health and safety.

input: What qualifies as Substantial Damage?
output: Substantial damage refers to any significant harm or failure that has a detrimental impact on the structural strength, performance, or flight characteristics of an aircraft. This can include major components such as wings, fuselage, or control surfaces that require extensive repair or replacement. However, certain types of damage are not considered substantial, such as engine failure in only one engine, minor cosmetic issues like bent fairings or dented skin, and minor damage to landing gear, wheels, tires, flaps, brakes, or wingtips. It is important for flight attendants to be aware of the criteria for substantial damage, as this can affect their duties and responsibilities during a flight, as well as any potential compensation or benefits that may be available in the event of such damage occurring.

input: What is considered the Trip Hour Period?
output: The trip hour period, also referred to as Time Away From Base (TAFB), is the total amount of time spent on duty during a flight attendant's schedule. This includes all hours from the start of their duty period at their base until the completion of their final duty period that terminates at their base. The trip hour period is an important factor in determining scheduling, compensation, and other aspects of a flight attendant's job, as it reflects the amount of time they spend away from home during their work assignments. Understanding the concept of trip hour periods can help flight attendants better plan for their schedules and manage their personal lives outside of work.

input: What is the role of the Association of Flight Attendants (AFA CWA) in relation to crew scheduling?
output: The Association of Flight Attendants (AFA CWA) is a labor union that represents the interests of flight attendants. In relation to crew scheduling, the AFA CWA negotiates with airlines on behalf of its members to establish fair and reasonable scheduling practices. This includes setting limits on duty periods, minimizing the impact of trip hour periods on flight attendants' personal lives, and ensuring that schedules are created in accordance with applicable laws and regulations. The AFA CWA also provides support and resources for flight attendants who may have concerns or issues related to their scheduling, helping them navigate the complexities of crew scheduling and advocate for their rights as employees. By working together with airlines and other stakeholders, the AFA CWA aims to create a safe, equitable, and sustainable work environment for flight attendants.

input: What is a Flight Attendant vacancy, and how can it be filled?
output: A Flight Attendant vacancy refers to an opening for the position of Flight Attendant within an airline's operations. This vacancy may arise due to various reasons, such as resignations, retirements, or other circumstances that lead to a need for a new Flight Attendant. To fill this vacancy, the Company has several options: 1. Transfer: The Company can offer the vacant position to a qualified Flight Attendant from another base or domicile, subject to seniority and qualification requirements. This transfer process takes into account the preferences of the affected Flight Attendants and aims to minimize disruptions to their schedules and lives. 2. Award: If no suitable candidate can be found through transfers, the Company may offer the vacancy to a new hire who has successfully completed the Flight Attendant training program. This process involves assessing applicants, conducting interviews, and selecting the most qualified candidate based on their skills, experience, and fit for the role. 3. Assignment: In some cases, the Company may choose to assign an existing Flight Attendant from another base or domicile to fill the vacancy temporarily. This assignment is typically based on seniority and qualifications and aims to maintain operational efficiency while ensuring that the affected Flight Attendants' schedules are minimally impacted. The specific process for filling a Flight Attendant vacancy may vary depending on the Company's policies, collective bargaining agreements, and applicable laws and regulations. However, the overall goal is to ensure a fair and efficient allocation of resources while maintaining safety, quality, and employee satisfaction.

input: As a flight attendant, how many hours am I guaranteed to receive per bid period?
output: You are guaranteed to receive the equivalent of 72 credited hours per bid period, unless you voluntarily reduce your schedule. This constitutes your bid period guarantee.

input: What happens if I'm on non-pay status for part of a month?
output: If you are on non-pay status for a portion of the month, you will be paid and credited flight pay at the applicable rate for each day on pay status or prorated minimum guarantee, whichever is greater. This ensures that you receive fair compensation even when not actively working.

input: What are the hourly rates of pay for flight attendants based on their longevity?
output: Flight attendants receive different hourly rates of pay based on their longevity with the company. For the first six months, the rate is $21.42, which increases to $21.85 and then $22.51 over the course of the first year. After one year, the rate increases again to $29.59 and continues to increase based on longevity up to a rate of $57.53 for flight attendants with 13 years of service.

input: As a flight attendant, how is my flight time calculated for pay purposes?
output: For pay purposes, your flight time is computed based on the actual block-to-block flight time or the scheduled flight time, whichever is greater, on a per-duty-period basis. This calculation includes all scheduled or actual flights and any other instances where you receive credit for flight time under this agreement, such as vacation, sick leave, training, deadheading, ferry flights, rescheduling or rerouting, Time Recoverable status, minimum guarantees, special assignment, and union activity.

input: Can I receive credit for flight time during my vacation?
output: Yes, you can receive credit for flight time during your vacation. Any time spent on vacation that involves duties related to the operation of an aircraft, such as serving as a Flight Attendant, will be counted towards your flight time for pay purposes.

input: How is my flight time affected when I'm on sick leave?
output: When you are on sick leave, your flight time may still be credited depending on the circumstances. If you are unable to work due to illness or injury but are still performing duties related to the operation of an aircraft, such as serving as a Flight Attendant, you will receive credit for that time towards your flight time for pay purposes. However, if your incapacity prevents you from performing any duties related to the operation of an aircraft, you will not receive credit for that time.

input: What is considered actual block-to-block flight time?
output: Actual block-to-block flight time refers to the total elapsed time between when the doors of the aircraft are closed for departure and when they are opened for arrival, excluding any ground time or turnaround time. This includes both the flying time and any delays that occur during the flight.

input: Can I receive credit for deadheading?
output: Yes, you can receive credit for deadheading. Deadheading refers to the time spent by a Flight Attendant traveling as a passenger on an aircraft without passengers when no flying duties are required. This time is counted towards your flight time for pay purposes.

input: How does rescheduling or rerouting affect my flight time?
output: Rescheduling or rerouting can impact your flight time for pay purposes. If you are reassigned to a different flight, the actual block-to-block flight time of the new flight will be used in computing your flight time, regardless of whether it is longer or shorter than the original scheduled flight time.

input: What is Time Recoverable status?
output: Time Recoverable status refers to a period during which a Flight Attendant is relieved of all duties and responsibilities related to the operation of an aircraft but remains on duty, typically in a hotel or other accommodations. During this time, you will receive credit for flight time towards your pay, even though you are not performing any duties related to the operation of an aircraft.

input: Can I receive credit for special assignments?
output: Yes, you can receive credit for special assignments. Special assignments refer to tasks or duties outside of your regular responsibilities as a Flight Attendant that are assigned by the airline, such as serving as a language instructor or participating in safety training exercises. The time spent on these assignments will be counted towards your flight time for pay purposes.

input: How does union activity impact my flight time?
output: Union activity can affect your flight time for pay purposes if the activities are related to the operation of an aircraft or the terms and conditions of your employment as a Flight Attendant. For example, attending union meetings or participating in negotiations may result in credit towards your flight time, while non-aviation-related union activities will not.

input: As a flight attendant, if I involuntarily lose all or part of my awarded pairings after the final bid award, what should I expect in terms of pay and credits?
output: If you involuntarily lose all or any part of your awarded pairings as reflected on your Final Bid Award, or involuntarily lose all or any part of pairings voluntarily picked up during the bid period, you will be paid and credited for the originally scheduled trip or the replacement trip, whichever is greater.

input: As a flight attendant, if I am assigned Time Recoverable Status and lose all or part of my awarded pairings, what will be the impact on my pay and credits?
output: If you have been assigned to Time Recoverable Status in accordance with Section 8.N. and involuntarily lose all or any part of your awarded pairings as reflected on your Final Bid Award, or involuntarily lose all or any part of pairings voluntarily picked up during the bid period, you will be paid the greater of the credited hours of the original trip or the replacement trip(s).

input: As a lineholder, if I am rescheduled or rerouted, how will my pay and credits be affected?
output: If you are a Lineholder who has been rescheduled or rerouted in accordance with Sections 8.Q. and 8.R., you will be paid the greater of the credited hours of the original trip or the rescheduled/rerouted trip. Additionally, you will be compensated at 150% of your current hourly rate for any additional pairing credit flown above your originally scheduled trip.
cba_section: QA_CBA Section 3D Line and Trip Guarantee

input: As a flight attendant, what happens if I am removed from an assigned trip after reporting and sent to Ready Reserve? How will my hours be credited towards my monthly guarantee?
output: In such a case, you shall be credited toward your monthly guarantee with the credited hours of the trip from which you were removed, the credited hours of the Ready Reserve period, or the credited hours of a new trip assigned during the Ready Reserve period, whichever is greater.

input: As a flight attendant, how are my Reserve assignments credited? What happens when I report for an assigned trip and get removed from it? How does this affect my monthly guarantee?
output: Reserve assignments, including Ready Reserve, out-of-base Reserve, Reserve Day(s) picked up from Open Time, or Reserve assigned under any other provision of this Agreement, are credited with four (4) hours per day or the credited hours of the assigned trip, whichever is greater. Upon reporting for an assigned trip, you will be treated the same as a Line holder for all purposes. If you are removed from an assigned trip after reporting and assigned to Ready Reserve status in accordance with Section 7.I, you will be credited toward your monthly guarantee with the credited hours of the trip from which you were removed, the credited hours of the Ready Reserve period, or the credited hours of a new trip assigned during the Ready Reserve period, whichever is greater. If you accept an assignment on your day off, you will be credited in addition to your monthly guarantee for the credited hours of the assignment, but if you are not contacted by Crew Scheduling or are contacted but not required to report, you will receive no Reserve credit, and your minimum guarantee shall apply.

input: What happens when a flight attendant exceeds the minimum monthly guarantee of seventy-two (72) credited hours?
output: When a Flight Attendant exceeds the minimum monthly guarantee of seventy-two (72) credited hours, they will be compensated for each additional credited hour up to eighty-five (85) credited hours at their hourly rate.

input: What is the compensation for flight attendants who exceed eighty-five (85) credited hours?
output: When a Flight Attendant exceeds eighty-five (85) credited hours, they will be compensated for each additional credited hour at the rate of 1.5 times their hourly rate. However, there are certain restrictions: (1) Sick Bank hours cannot be used to calculate Overtime Incentive Pay and (2) Flight Attendants cannot earn Overtime Incentive Pay through trip trading or dropping trips with another Flight Attendant; in such cases, the credited hours gained will be calculated at the Flight Attendants' hourly rate.

input: What is the payment rate for a flight attendant working the lead "A" position?
output: A Flight Attendant working the lead "A" position will be paid at an additional rate of two dollars fifty cents ($2.50) per hour for all credited hours in the pairing.

input: What happens when a Flight Attendant is required to deadhead via flight, excluding training?
output: When the Company requires a Flight Attendant to deadhead via flight, excluding training, the Flight Attendant shall be credited at their applicable rate for one hundred percent (100%) of the greater of actual or scheduled time of the deadhead flight.

input: How is a Flight Attendant credited when they are required to deadhead via surface transportation?
output: When the Company requires a Flight Attendant to deadhead via surface transportation, a Flight Attendant shall be credited for one (1) hour of flight time at the Flight Attendant’s applicable rate for every two (2) hours of deadhead time based on the greater of actual or scheduled time of the deadhead. Scheduled deadhead time shall be based on AAA mileage at 43 miles per hour.

input: What is the basis for calculating credited flight time when a Flight Attendant is deadheading via surface transportation?
output: Scheduled deadhead time shall be based on AAA mileage at 43 miles per hour when calculating credited flight time for a Flight Attendant who is deadheading via surface transportation.

input: Can a Flight Attendant be required to deadhead via surface transportation instead of flying?
output: Yes, the Company may require a Flight Attendant to deadhead via surface transportation instead of flying, depending on operational needs and availability.

input: How is the applicable rate for a Flight Attendant determined when they are credited for deadheading?
output: The applicable rate for a Flight Attendant when they are credited for deadheading is based on their position and seniority within the Company, as well as any relevant collective bargaining agreements.

input: Is there a minimum amount of time that a Flight Attendant must be credited when deadheading via surface transportation?
output: Yes, a Flight Attendant shall be credited for at least one (1) hour of flight time when they are required to deadhead via surface transportation. The credit is based on the greater of actual or scheduled time of the deadhead.

input: Can a Flight Attendant decline a request to deadhead?
output: A Flight Attendant may be required to deadhead as part of their duties, and they cannot decline such requests unless they have a valid reason for doing so in accordance with Company policies and procedures.

input: As a flight attendant on a ferry flight, how is my work time calculated for scheduling purposes?
output: When you are positioned via a ferry flight, your work time will be credited at 75% of the greater value between your actual or scheduled time. This applies to your applicable rate as a flight attendant.

input: What happens when I am required to be onboard during an aircraft repositioning event?
output: When you are required by the company to be onboard while the aircraft is being repositioned on the ground, such as moving to or from a remote location like a hangar, you will be credited with three-tenths (.3) of one hour at your applicable rate. This credit will count towards your monthly guarantee as a flight attendant.

input: As a flight attendant, when am I required to be onboard the aircraft with passengers?
output: You are required to be onboard the aircraft with passengers when it is scheduled for departure or already in blocks with passengers. In this case, you will be paid and credited at your hourly rate of pay toward your minimum monthly guarantee for all such time.

input: How is ground holding time defined for pay purposes?
output: Ground holding time for pay purposes is determined as all time beginning forty-five (45) minutes after the scheduled departure time or forty-five (45) minutes after the scheduled arrival time at the end of a duty period. This time will be considered when calculating your payment and credits toward your minimum monthly guarantee.

input: What happens if I am required to remain with passengers on or off the aircraft during a non-scheduled stop at a non-Spirit station?
output: If you are required to remain with passengers on or off the aircraft during a non-scheduled stop at a non-Spirit station where there is no customer service assistance available, you will be paid and credited at your hourly rate of pay above your minimum monthly guarantee for all such time. This additional compensation recognizes the unique circumstances and responsibilities you may face in these situations.

input: As a flight attendant, I've been scheduled to work more than 15 hours in a single duty period. What compensation am I entitled to receive?
output: You are entitled to receive fifty percent (50%) of your applicable hourly rate for each hour on duty over fifteen (15) hours. This compensation is provided to ensure that you are fairly compensated for any additional time spent on duty beyond the standard work requirements.

input: As a flight attendant, if I am assigned to work on New Year's Day, July 4th, Thanksgiving Day, and Christmas Day, what additional compensation can I expect?
output: You will receive two hundred percent (200%) of the greater of actual or scheduled credit time in addition to all other compensation. This applies only if you complete all segments of the pairing within which the holiday falls.

input: What happens if I am assigned to Ready Reserve on a holiday but not called in for an assignment? Do I still receive holiday pay?
output: Yes, if you are assigned to Ready Reserve on a holiday and report for duty, you will receive holiday pay. However, available reserves who are not required to report for an assignment on the holiday do not qualify for Holiday Pay.

input: Can I expect any special treatment or considerations if I am scheduled to work on multiple holidays in a row?
output: The regulations mentioned do not provide specific details about special treatment or considerations for flight attendants working on multiple holidays in a row. However, it is important to note that you will still receive the applicable compensation as outlined in the regulations if you complete all segments of the pairing within which each holiday falls.

input: If I am scheduled for a layover on a holiday, am I eligible for holiday pay?
output: The regulations do not specifically mention layovers in relation to holiday pay. However, if you are assigned to work on a holiday and complete all segments of the pairing within which the holiday falls, you will be eligible for holiday pay regardless of whether you have a layover during that time.

input: As a flight attendant, can I choose to swap my scheduled holiday duties with another crew member?
output: The regulations do not mention any provisions for swapping holiday duties with other crew members. If you are assigned to work on a holiday and complete all segments of the pairing within which the holiday falls, you will receive the applicable compensation as outlined in the regulations.

input: As an available reserve, if I am not required to report for an assignment on a holiday, can I still receive Holiday Pay?
output: No, as an available reserve, you will not qualify for Holiday Pay if you are not required to report for an assignment on the holiday. Only flight attendants who are assigned to work on the holiday and complete all segments of the pairing within which it falls are eligible for Holiday Pay.

input: As a flight attendant, how am I credited for attending training or meetings?
output: As a flight attendant, you will be credited for each day of scheduled training or meeting at a rate of four (4) hours per day or trip hours missed during the training or meeting period, whichever is greater.
cba_section: QA_CBA Section 3P Training and Meeting Pay

input: How am I credited as a reserve flight attendant when attending training or meetings?
output: As a reserve flight attendant, you will be credited four (4) hours for each day of travel and/or training to be applied toward the minimum monthly guarantee when required to attend, or travel to or from training or meeting on a Reserve duty day.
cba_section: QA_CBA Section 3P Training and Meeting Pay

input: What happens if I need to travel to or from training or meetings on my scheduled day off?
output: If you are required to travel to or from training or meetings on your scheduled day off, you will be credited four (4) hours in addition to your minimum monthly guarantee.
cba_section: QA_CBA Section 3P Training and Meeting Pay

input: How am I credited when assigned to training or meetings on my day off?
output: When assigned to training or meetings on your day off, you will be credited four (4) hours in addition to your minimum monthly guarantee.
cba_section: QA_CBA Section 3P Training and Meeting Pay

input: How is Home Study paid and credited for flight attendants?
output: Home Study that is related to recurrent or requalification training will be paid and credited at one (1) hour at the applicable rate, while Home Study not related to recurrent or requalification training will be paid in accordance with Section 10.B.8 and above the minimum monthly guarantee. Completing Home Study related to recurrent and requalification training will result in four (4) hours of pay and credit above the minimum monthly guarantee.
cba_section: QA_CBA Section 3P Training and Meeting Pay

input: As a flight attendant returning from a leave of absence, what rate of pay can I expect during my requalification training?
output: During your Requalification Training after a leave of absence, you will receive training pay at your applicable hourly rates.

input: What happens if my trade or drop causes me to drop below my monthly guarantee?
output: If your trade or drop causes you to drop below your monthly guarantee, then according to the regulations, your guarantee will be reduced by the number of hours the trade or drop takes you below guarantee. This means that your guarantee will be adjusted to reflect the change in your work schedule and ensure fair compensation for all involved parties.
cba_section: QA_CBA Section 3R Trip Trades and Drops Pay

input: As a flight attendant, how am I compensated when working on a Junior Assigned flight?
output: When you are assigned to work on a Junior Assigned flight, you will be paid and credited at the rate of 1.5 times your hourly rate for that specific trip or pairing, in addition to receiving your monthly guarantee.

input: As a flight attendant, how am I compensated for drug and alcohol tests?
output: As a flight attendant, you are paid and credited at your applicable hourly rate in addition to guaranteeing one-half (.5) hour of pay for each drug test and one-half (.5) hour of pay for each alcohol test, or one (1) hour of pay for a combined drug/alcohol test. However, new hires before becoming qualified and Flight Attendants receiving a confirmed positive result are not eligible for payment under this provision.
cba_section: QA_CBA Section 3T Alcohol and Drug Testing Pay

input: What happens if the testing facility is not located on airport premises?
output: If the testing facility is not situated on airport premises, your employer will provide transportation to and from the testing location for drug and alcohol tests.
cba_section: QA_CBA Section 3T Alcohol and Drug Testing Pay

input: What are the designated pay periods for Flight Attendants?
output: The designated pay periods for Flight Attendants are from the 1st through the 15th and the 16th through month-end.

input: When will I be paid for the 1st through the 15th pay period?
output: You will be paid for the 1st through the 15th pay period on the 15th, which includes one-half (1/2) of your minimum guarantee from the current bid period plus the per diem, overtime, junior assignment pay and all other amounts above guarantee due from the prior bid period.

input: When will I be paid for the 16th through the month-end pay period?
output: You will be paid for the 16th through the month-end pay period on the last day of the month, which includes one-half (1/2) of your minimum guarantee from the current bid period.

input: What happens if my designated payday falls on a Saturday or Sunday?
output: If your designated payday falls on a Saturday or Sunday, the preceding Friday will be the payday.

input: What happens if my designated payday falls on a holiday?
output: If your designated payday falls on a holiday, the preceding business day which is not a holiday will be the payday.

input: Can I change the bank where my paycheck is directly deposited?
output: Yes, you can change the bank where your paycheck is directly deposited. However, if you designate a new bank, you may not make another change for three (3) months.

input: What happens if there is an error in my pay that results in a shortage of more than $50?
output: If there is an error in your pay that results in a shortage of more than $50, the Company will pay you via direct deposit or overnight mail within four (4) business days from the time at which the error is confirmed by the Crew Payroll Department to have occurred.

input: What happens if there is an error in my pay that results in a shortage of less than $50?
output: If there is an error in your pay that results in a shortage of less than $50, the error will be paid on the next check following confirmation. Confirmation will be made within four (4) business days from the time the error is brought to the Company’s attention.

input: As a flight attendant, when am I eligible for the annual $150 uniform credit?
output: You are eligible for the annual $150 uniform credit after completing twelve (12) months of active service with the airline. This credit will be provided on your anniversary date each year.

input: Can I carry over my unused uniform credit to the next year?
output: No, the uniform credit must be used prior to your next longevity pay increase each year or it will expire ("use it or lose it").

input: What happens if I don't use my uniform credit before it expires?
output: If you do not use your uniform credit before it expires, the credit will no longer be available for use. It is important to plan and utilize your uniform credit within the given timeframe.

input: What percentage of our sales revenue will go towards commission, and how is this amount distributed among the flight attendants?
output: At least four percent (4%) of your sales revenue will be allocated as commission, which will be equally divided among all Flight Attendants working on the same flight.

input: What is the international pay override for flights outside the contiguous United States?
output: The international pay override for flights from the forty-eight (48) contiguous United States to points outside the forty-eight (48) contiguous United States and for any flights between points outside the forty-eight (48) contiguous United States is five percent (5%) of the credit time. This override does not apply to Alaska, Canada, Mexico, and the island nations of the Caribbean between 15 degrees north latitude and 28 degrees north latitude, except for Cuba.

input: Are there any exceptions to the international pay override for flights within the Caribbean?
output: Yes, there are exceptions to the international pay override for flights within the Caribbean. The override does not apply to Alaska, Canada, Mexico, and the island nations of the Caribbean between 15 degrees north latitude and 28 degrees north latitude, except for Cuba.

input: How is the international pay override calculated for flights to Cuba?
output: The international pay override for flights to Cuba is calculated as five percent (5%) of the credit time. Cuba is considered an exception to the general rule that the override does not apply to Alaska, Canada, Mexico, and the island nations of the Caribbean between 15 degrees north latitude and 28 degrees north latitude.

input: Can I receive international pay for flights within the contiguous United States?
output: No, you cannot receive international pay for flights within the contiguous United States. The override only applies to flights from the forty-eight (48) contiguous United States to points outside the forty-eight (48) contiguous United States and for any flights between points outside the forty-eight (48) contiguous United States, except for Alaska, Canada, Mexico, and the island nations of the Caribbean between 15 degrees north latitude and 28 degrees north latitude, except for Cuba.

input: Are there any specific rules regarding international pay for flights to Alaska?
output: No, there are no specific rules regarding international pay for flights to Alaska mentioned in the provided text. The override only applies to flights from the forty-eight (48) contiguous United States to points outside the forty-eight (48) contiguous United States and for any flights between points outside the forty-eight (48) contiguous United States, except for Alaska, Canada, Mexico, and the island nations of the Caribbean between 15 degrees north latitude and 28 degrees north latitude, except for Cuba.

input: Can I receive international pay for flights to Canada or Mexico?
output: No, you cannot receive international pay for flights to Canada or Mexico. The override only applies to flights from the forty-eight (48) contiguous United States to points outside the forty-eight (48) contiguous United States and for any flights between points outside the forty-eight (48) contiguous United States, except for Alaska, Canada, Mexico, and the island nations of the Caribbean between 15 degrees north latitude and 28 degrees north latitude, except for Cuba.

input: Are there any specific rules regarding international pay for flights to the island nations of the Caribbean?
output: No, there are no specific rules regarding international pay for flights to the island nations of the Caribbean mentioned in the provided text. The override only applies to flights from the forty-eight (48) contiguous United States to points outside the forty-eight (48) contiguous United States and for any flights between points outside the forty-eight (48) contiguous United States, except for Alaska, Canada, Mexico, and the island nations of the Caribbean between 15 degrees north latitude and 28 degrees north latitude, except for Cuba.

input: Can I receive international pay for flights to any other countries outside the forty-eight (48) contiguous United States?
output: Yes, you can receive international pay for flights to any other countries outside the forty-eight (48) contiguous United States that are not specifically mentioned as exceptions in the provided text. The override is five percent (5%) of the credit time for these flights.

input: As a flight attendant, what are my rights regarding lodging when assigned to training away from base requiring an overnight stay?
output: According to the regulations, your company is required to provide comfortable, safe and adequate single occupancy lodging for you at all layover stations, while assigned to training away from base requiring an overnight stay, or if you are assigned or awarded temporary duty out of base. This means that when you are sent for training away from your base, the company must provide you with appropriate accommodations for the duration of your stay.

input: What should I do if my hotel room is not clean and available for check-in within thirty (30) minutes of arrival?
output: If your hotel room is not clean and available for check-in within thirty (30) minutes of arrival, you may contact Crew Scheduling and request alternate accommodations. The company has a responsibility to ensure that you have access to suitable lodging, so if your initial room is not available, they should provide you with an alternative option.

input: What happens if I am notified by Crew Scheduling of a delay and my hotel room cannot be extended until one hour and thirty (1:30) minutes before the rescheduled departure time?
output: If your hotel room cannot be extended until one hour and thirty (1:30) minutes before the rescheduled departure time, then the start time of your duty period will not be adjusted. However, you are not required to check out of the hotel room until one hour and thirty (1:30) minutes before the rescheduled departure time, subject to hotel availability.

input: What should I do if I am assigned a duty period that is four (4) hours block-to-block or more on the ground at any station away from base?
output: If you are assigned a duty period that is four (4) hours block-to-block or more on the ground at any station away from base, your company shall provide comfortable, safe and adequate single occupancy lodging for you. This means that they must provide you with appropriate accommodations to ensure that you have a comfortable and restful stay during your layover.

input: What are my responsibilities regarding hotel charges not approved by the company?
output: It is your responsibility as a flight attendant to ensure that all hotel charges not approved by the company (e.g., meals, personal phone calls, in-room movies, etc.) are paid prior to departure from the hotel. This means that you must be mindful of any additional expenses you may incur during your stay and make sure to settle them before leaving the hotel.

input: As a flight attendant, what should I do if my hotel room is not available and I believe my minimum rest requirements may not be met?
output: If your hotel room is not available and you believe that your minimum rest requirements may not be met, you should contact Crew Scheduling to discuss adjusting your Check-in Time. The company has a responsibility to ensure that you have access to suitable lodging that allows for adequate rest before your duty period begins.

input: What does it mean to adjust my Check-in Time to allow for eight (8) hours of rest “behind the door”?
output: Adjusting your Check-in Time to allow for eight (8) hours of rest “behind the door” means that your duty period will start later than originally scheduled, giving you sufficient time to rest before beginning your work responsibilities. This adjustment is made to ensure that you have met the minimum rest requirements as mandated by regulations and are well-rested before starting your duties.

input: What are the minimum standards for hotel accommodations as set forth in the Hotel Minimum Standards?
output: The minimum standards for hotel accommodations include free courtesy car/van transportation, twenty-four-hour front desk operation, expedited check-in and checkout procedures, reliable message service, reliable wake-up service, suitable housekeeping services, available on-premises restaurant and room service or walking distance to a restaurant, free local and toll-free calls, free high-speed internet access in the room and business center (if available), complimentary toiletries, and recreational facilities such as an exercise room.

input: What are the required hotel security measures as outlined in the Hotel Required Security guidelines?
output: The required hotel security measures include being located in a safe area, patrolled by police and/or private security; limiting and monitoring entrances to the hotel; providing well-lit hallways; equipping guest rooms with sprinklers and smoke detectors; and ensuring adequate security of door access to guest rooms (e.g., chain lock, dead bolt, key lock, and/or peephole). The Company should avoid reserving first-floor rooms when possible.

input: What are the contractual location standards for hotels as specified in the Hotel Contractual Location Standards?
output: The contractual location standards for hotels include being within a reasonable distance from the airport, situated in a safe neighborhood for walking, and having at least one hotel in downtown or urban areas or areas of cultural or historical significance for layovers in cities with multiple crew hotels. Flight Attendants on a layover of 18 hours or more will be overnighted in this specific hotel.

input: What are the contractual room requirements as specified in the Contractual Room Requirements?
output: The contractual room requirements include a single occupancy with double, queen, or king-sized beds; being clean and neat; having an adequate size; linen and towels changed before each occupancy; a shower; rooms on the second floor or above if possible, away from traffic, parking lots, elevators, and ice machines; air conditioners and heater filters changed every thirty days; cable or satellite television; hairdryer, coffee maker, iron, and ironing board; non-smoking rooms and smoking rooms upon request.

input: What are the preferred items as listed with Hotel Accommodations?
output: The preferred items include van service to theaters and restaurants; discounts of 20% or more in hotel restaurant(s) and lounge(s); check cashing privileges of at least fifty dollars ($50.00); complimentary coffee; complimentary holiday meals and activities; close proximity to historical and cultural attractions; and close proximity to shopping and entertainment options.

input: What happens if the company doesn't provide transportation to the flight attendant between the airport and their place of lodging?
output: If the company fails to provide transportation as stated, you are entitled to receive actual expenses incurred for your own transportation. However, keep in mind that the company may require receipts for reimbursement.

input: How long does the company have to provide transportation at layover stations?
output: The company must provide transportation at layover stations within forty-five (45) minutes after the block-in time of your flight. If they fail to do so, you are eligible for reimbursement of actual expenses incurred for transportation between the airport and your hotel.

input: Can I claim expenses for transportation if I choose a different mode of transportation than what the company provides?
output: No, you can only claim expenses for transportation that is necessary and directly related to your travel between the airport and your place of lodging. If the company offers transportation and you choose an alternative method, you may not be eligible for reimbursement.

input: What happens if I don't submit receipts for my transportation expenses?
output: Failure to provide receipts may result in your claim being denied or delayed. It is important to keep all necessary documentation and submit it promptly to ensure timely reimbursement.

input: As a flight attendant, I am assigned to work in a different base than my usual one. Can I get reimbursed for parking expenses if I don't need a decal at this new location?
output: Yes, you are entitled to reimbursement for parking expenses up to the amount that would have been paid at your usual base, upon request and if you do not require a parking decal at the alternate location.

input: As a flight attendant, when am I eligible to receive the per diem rate while away from my base?
output: You are eligible to receive the per diem rate of two dollars sixty-eight cents ($2.68) per hour or fraction thereof beginning at check-in time and ending at release time when you are away from your base, including during training assignments and temporary duty (TDY).

input: How is the per diem rate adjusted annually?
output: The per diem rate is adjusted annually on May 1st based on the prevailing Consumer Price Index (CPI) rate. The adjustment is rounded up to the next cent, and if there is no increase in the CPI rate, no increase will be applied to the per diem rate.

input: Am I entitled to per diem during Ready Reserve duty?
output: Yes, as a Flight Attendant assigned to Ready Reserve, you are eligible to receive per diem for all time spent on Ready Reserve duty.

input: Can I choose between per diem and actual expenses when on special assignment out of base?
output: As a flight attendant on special assignment in or out of base, you have the option to be paid either per diem or for all reasonable actual expenses incurred supported by receipts, whichever is greater. This allows you to choose the most beneficial compensation method based on your specific situation.

input: How often will I receive the per diem payment?
output: Per diem shall be paid at least once per bid period to ensure timely compensation for time spent away from base.

input: Can flight attendants participating in training programs benefit from the hotel buyback program?
output: No, Flight Attendants attending training may not participate in the hotel buyback program.

input: What is the purpose of the hotel buyback program?
output: The hotel buyback program aims to provide financial compensation to flight attendants for their overnight stays at specified hotels during layovers or trips, helping them cover some of the expenses incurred while away from home.

input: How can flight attendants access the list of hotels included in the hotel buyback program?
output: The Company will update and publish the list of hotels included in the program electronically as necessary, making it easily accessible for flight attendants to consult and verify their eligibility for reimbursement.

input: Are there any restrictions on the duration of a layover or trip for a flight attendant to be eligible for hotel buyback compensation?
output: There are no specific restrictions mentioned in the text regarding the duration of a layover or trip for a flight attendant to be eligible for hotel buyback compensation. However, it is important to note that the Company may exercise its discretion and amend or change the guidelines at any time.

input: Can flight attendants claim reimbursement for expenses incurred at hotels not included in the hotel buyback program?
output: No, flight attendants can only claim reimbursement for overnight stays at specified hotels included in the hotel buyback program. Expenses incurred at other hotels will not be covered under this program.

input: How often is the list of hotels included in the hotel buyback program updated?
output: The Company will update the list of hotels included in the program electronically "as necessary," which implies that the frequency of updates may vary depending on the Company's discretion and any changes to the program.

input: Can I get reimbursed for my Global Entry application if I am a Flight Attendant?
output: Yes, you can be reimbursed for your Global Entry application as a Flight Attendant. To receive the reimbursement, please submit your request along with any necessary documentation in the manner directed by the Company.

input: Am I eligible for passport renewal reimbursement if I am a Flight Attendant?
output: Yes, you are eligible for passport renewal reimbursement as a Flight Attendant. To receive the reimbursement, please submit your request along with any necessary documentation in the manner directed by the Company. The Company will cover the cost of expediting the passport but not the costs associated with replacing lost, stolen or damaged passports.

input: What are the regulations regarding the wearing of uniforms by flight attendants?
output: As per company regulations, flight attendants must wear their prescribed uniform at all times while on duty or during any special assignment or event where they are identified as a Spirit Airlines Flight Attendant. The uniform should be worn as specified in the Flight Attendant Manual, with limited exceptions granted by the Inflight Department. It is the responsibility of the flight attendant to maintain their uniform clean, pressed, well-fitted, and in good repair.
cba_section: QA_CBA Section 5A Flight Attendant Uniform Obligations

input: What are the specific items that must be included in a flight attendant's uniform?
output: All flight attendant uniforms must include the following items: (1) Name tag, (2) Pair of wings, (3) Apron, (4) Trench Coat, and (5) Lanyard. The specific combination of tops and bottoms required for a complete uniform set is determined by either Option 1 or Option 2. Option 1 requires three tops (including one dress shirt or polo) and one bottom (with one belt if applicable), while Option 2 requires three tops (including one dress shirt or polo), one bottom, and one belt (if applicable). The company provides the first name tag and pair of wings, which can be retained by flight attendants who complete six months of service prior to separation. Replacement name tags and wings due to normal wear are at the expense of the company. Flight attendants may affix their identification badge to their uniforms and do not need to use a lanyard.

input: What are the rules regarding the retention of name tags and wings by flight attendants?
output: The company provides the first name tag and pair of wings for each flight attendant. These items may be retained by a flight attendant who completes six months of service prior to separation. Replacement name tags and wings due to normal wear are at the expense of the company. Flight attendants have the option to affix their identification badge to their uniforms without using a lanyard.

input: What optional uniform items are available for purchase by flight attendants?
output: In addition to the required uniform items, flight attendants have the option to purchase a Sweater Vest and other optional uniform items that may be prescribed in the Flight Attendant Manual. The Company also allows the official Union pin to be worn on a visible location on all Flight Attendant uniforms, with the right to designate the specific location reserved for the company.

input: What is the policy on purchasing a maternity uniform?
output: The company provides an approved maternity uniform for flight attendants to purchase. Additionally, flight attendants have the option to purchase their own maternity pieces, as long as they receive approval from the company beforehand.

input: What are the requirements for providing an inflight bag, suitcase, and garment bag?
output: Flight attendants are required to provide their own black inflight bag, suitcase, and garment bag that comply with size limitations set by the company. They are responsible for maintaining the cleanliness and good repair of these luggage items.

input: How and when do flight attendants purchase their initial uniform during training?
output: Flight attendants are required to purchase their initial uniform using a combination of credit card, personal check, or payroll deductions during their initial training. The maximum deduction from each paycheck is $25, except in the case of a final payment upon resignation or termination. The company will provide any required special inflight attire at no cost to the flight attendant.

input: What happens if a part of the uniform or luggage is damaged or lost while on duty due to no fault of the flight attendant?
output: If any part of the uniform or luggage is damaged or lost while on duty due to no fault of the flight attendant, the company will repair or replace it with proper verification from the Flight Attendant Manager or designee.

input: What should I do if my uniform or luggage gets damaged while on duty?
output: If your uniform or luggage becomes damaged during your duties, you should report it to the Flight Attendant Manager or their designee for proper verification. The company will then be responsible for repairing or replacing the damaged item at no cost to you, including shipping fees if applicable.

input: What happens if I submit a defective uniform item?
output: If you report a defective uniform item and it is confirmed by the company to be faulty, they will replace it at no charge to you, including covering shipping costs or crediting your uniform account.

input: Are there any differences in pricing for similar uniform pieces?
output: No, identical uniform items such as pants, blouses, and dresses will have the same price regardless of any designations like "tall" or "maternity".

input: As a flight attendant, when do I receive my uniform credit?
output: You receive your uniform credit per Section 3.V. simultaneously with your longevity pay increase.

input: Can I use my uniform credit for any uniform piece?
output: Yes, all uniform credits may be applied toward the Flight Attendant's choice of uniform pieces and are not restricted to required items.

input: How many replacement uniform orders can I receive from the company each year?
output: The Company will cover the shipping costs of Flight Attendant replacement uniform pieces for a Flight Attendant up to four (4) orders per calendar year.

input: What happens to my additional uniform credits if I don't use them by the end of the year?
output: The additional uniform credits will expire at the end of each calendar year.

input: As a flight attendant, what happens if I fly more than 600 block hours in a calendar year?
output: You will not receive any additional uniform credits beyond the one hundred and fifty dollars ($150.00) provided for flying a minimum of 600 block hours in a calendar year.

input: Can I carry over my additional uniform credits to the next year if I don't use them?
